conclusion: The p-V image of an ideal gas changes from state A to B and then to C. The temperature of the gas in state A is 27Â°C.
From A to B, the process is isochoric (constant volume).
Initial state A: \( T_A = 27^\circ C = 300 K \), Pressure at A: \( p_A = 3 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \), Pressure at B: \( p_B = 1 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \).

premise: Using the relation for isochoric process \(\frac{p_A}{T_A} = \frac{p_B}{T_B}\).

conclusion: From B to C, the process is isobaric (constant pressure).
Volume at B: \( V_B = 1 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3 \), Volume at C: \( V_C = 3 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3 \).

premise: Using the relation for isobaric process \(\frac{V_B}{T_B} = \frac{V_C}{T_C}\).
The change in internal energy \(\Delta U\) is related to temperature change. Since \( T_A = T_C \), \(\Delta T = 0\).
The work done \( W \) is for the isobaric process from B to C: \(W = p_B (V_C - V_B)\).
Using the First Law of Thermodynamics: \(\Delta U = W + Q\). Since \(\Delta U = 0\).
Correcting the sign for heat transfer based on the First Law of Thermodynamics.
